patterns.pattern: First-time contributors (0 prior PRs) with missing critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, test coverage, CI status) face 7-8% confidence penalty and baseline merge rejection unless compensated by explicit credibility signals (maintainer/trusted/experienced labels) or strong structural signals (XS size label)
XS and S size labels correlate with 26-28% merge rates and provide +2-4% boost over baseline; XS label is strongest compensatory signal for weak author history and missing metadata

L and XL size labels are strong rejection signals correlating with 15-20% merge rates, overriding compensatory signals and creating deterministic rejection risk, particularly for first-time contributors
Multi-category touches (3+ categories or multi-channel PRs) impose 25-30% penalty on merge likelihood for weak authors, signaling scope creep or misclassification risk

High-priority categories (agents, gateway, commands, cli) provide +15-25% baseline uplift; infrastructure/signals areas provide mid-tier +10-20% uplift; low-priority areas (docker, docs-only) provide minimal or negative uplift
Fix-type changes provide +10-20% merge probability boost over feature additions; documentation-only changes from first-time contributors have depressed baseline (20-30%)
Authors with 100% prior merge rate history (even single prior PR ) signal >50% merge likelihood when paired with focused scope, narrow category, and fix classification
Authors with 40%+ prior merge rate significantly exceed 24% baseline and are strong merge candidates independent of size/scope, particularly when paired with experienced-contributor label

Authors with established history (50+ prior PRs) demonstrate persistence/commitment signal and retain moderate merge likelihood (25-30%) even when merge rate is below baseline, especially with XS size label
Experienced-contributor label provides +5-15% credibility boost and substantially mitigates missing metadata penalties for authors with 6+ prior PRs
Maintainer label acts as powerful credibility amplifier (90%+ merge rate signal) and overrides size/scope rejection signals, enabling high-priority cross-channel work approval
Authors with 15-25% prior merge rate near baseline benefit from narrow scope and fix-type classification for moderate (34-40%) merge likelihood; XS/S size labels provide necessary compensatory boost
Authors with 0% prior merge rate across 2+ attempts (low-merge-author trajectory) face rejection pattern, particularly when combined with L size label or feature-type changes

Narrow scope (single component/channel) provides +5-10% boost; issue references provide +5-10% specificity boost; these mitigate but do not overcome first-time author baseline without compensatory size/category signals

Missing all critical metadata (LoC, files_changed, has_tests, ci_green) imposes consistent 7-8% confidence penalty; penalty is substantially mitigated (reduced to 1-3%) by explicit size labels (XS) or established author history (50%+ merge rate)
